Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complications including an epidural abscess, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, atrial thrombus, and NSTEMI. The patient presented with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) with dense, large right-sided infiltrate, which is now improving. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely secondary to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration PNA, along with pulmonary edema. Antibiotics (vanc/aztreonam) have been continued for aspiration/HAP.

The patient has persistent fevers, possibly due to known PNA or enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis. There is no new source identified for the fever, and deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is unlikely given recent anticoagulation and now subcutaneous heparin. Effusions on CT do not appear to be empyemas, and glucan/galactomannan tests are negative. Clostridium difficile (C. diff) is a possibility due to increased diarrhea and clindamycin use. Drug fever would be diagnosed by exclusion.

The patient has a left leg contracture, which may be due to a central process, inflammatory or infectious arthropathy, or other causes. An MRI is pending, and

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic renal insufficiency. He was admitted to the ICU for fevers, lethargy, and respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation with APRV, then AC, and finally PS mode. He has been receiving vancomycin, aztreonam, and clindamycin for pneumonia, but these antibiotics were stopped on day 7 and 10, respectively. The patient's abdominal pain remains unchanged since the last imaging on 10/26. His blood cultures are negative for C. difficile. The patient has also had episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, troponin leak, altered mental status, and right atrial appendage thrombus. His respiratory status has improved, but he still requires supplemental oxygen. His leukocytosis is improving, and he has been weaned off sedation. The patient's renal function remains stable, but he is oliguric. His nutritional status needs to be addressed, and he requires a nutrition consult for tube feeds. The patient's gout is not currently an acute issue. His code status is full code, and he is currently admitted to the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient initially presented with respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia. Despite improvements

The patient presents with respiratory distress and has been admitted to the ICU. The patient's vital signs show a fever, sinus tachycardia, and hypotension. The ABG results indicate a pH of 7.42, PaCO2 of 45 mmHg, PaO2 of 290, and HCO3- of 29 mEq/L.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic renal insufficiency who was admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia. The patient has been intubated and is currently on pressure support ventilation. The patient's abdominal pain, nutrition, sepsis, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, and altered mental status are being closely monitored. The patient's medications include Vancomycin, Aztreonam, Lasix, gabapentin, fentanyl patch, and prednisone. The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, lactic acid levels, and troponin-T. The patient's imaging shows worsening chest x-ray with increased atelectasis. The patient's contracture in the left leg is concerning for central process or gouty arthritis. An MRI has been ordered to further evaluate this. The patient's pain control is being addressed with increased gabapentin and fentanyl patch. The patient's fevers and rising leukocytosis suggest an ongoing infection, and fungal markers are negative. The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response required cardiovascular support. The patient's troponin leak is being managed with rate control and statin therapy. The patient's altered mental status is likely due to AMS or infection, and the right atrial appendage thrombus is being monitored without anticoagulation.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic renal insufficiency. He presented from rehabilitation for fevers and lethargy and was subsequently intubated for pneumonia of the entire right lung. The patient has respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia and is currently on mechanical ventilation. He has been treated with vancomycin, aztreonam, and clindamycin for pneumonia, but his condition has not improved. The patient also has a leg contracture concerning for central process or gouty arthritis of the knee. He has chronic pain exacerbated by weaning sedation, for which gabapentin and fentanyl patch have been increased. The patient's fevers and rising leukocytosis are unexplained, and he has been evaluated for sepsis. He also had atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response that required central venous line placement and neosynephrine for blood pressure support. The patient has a troponin leak after an episode of atrial fibrillation earlier in the week, and his creatinine levels have increased. He initially had altered mental status likely due to fevers and infection, but currently, his mental status is difficult to assess due to large amounts of sedation. The patient has a history of gout and is being monitored for it. He has anemia with no clear source of blood loss, and his electroly

The MRI scan revealed a fluid collection adjacent to the right facet joint between L4 and L5, which demonstrates restricted diffusion. This could be secondary to blood products, but associated infection cannot be excluded.

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic renal insufficiency. He was recently hospitalized for an epidural abscess and bacteremia caused by Pan-Sensitive Enterococcus. The patient presented with fevers and lethargy and subsequently intubated for pneumonia of the entire right lung. He has multiple medical complications including respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia, a left leg contracture possibly due to gouty arthritis, pain control issues, fevers and rising leukocytosis, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, troponin leak, acute mental status change, and a right atrial appendage thrombus.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia: The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation to support his respiratory function. However, there is worsening of the condition as evidenced by increased atelectasis on chest X-ray. The patient may require further interventions such as bronchoscopy or surgical intervention to clear the infection and improve lung function.

2. Left leg contracture possibly due to gouty arthritis: The patient has a history of gout, and the tenderness of the left knee suggests gouty arthritis. This condition can lead to joint deformity and limited mobility. The patient may need to be referred to a rheumatologist for definitive diagnosis and treatment.

3. Pain control issues: The

   76M (h/o asthma, gout and recent complicated hospital course including
   epidural abscess requring surgery, enterococcus bactermia, aortic
   endocarditis, septic emboli to brain, atrial thrombus, NSTEMI) p/w
   aspiration PNA with dense, large R-sided infiltrate, now improving.
   # Hypoxemic respiratory failure on vent: Likely [**1-17**] to HAP/aspiration
   PNA + pulmonary edema.  CXR improving.
   - Continue abx (vanc/aztreonam Day [**9-28**]) for aspiration/HAP

   - Bronchodilators
   - Weaned PS to [**4-19**] now, CXR improved, but still poor mental status
   # Persistent fevers: Known PNA
 but would expect him to be afebrile at
   this time from PNA.  Enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and
   discitis stable. No new source identified. DVT unlikely given recent
   anticoagulation and now SQ heparin.  Effusions on CT do not appear to
   be empyemas.  Glucan/Galactomannan negative.  C .diff a posibility
   given increased diarrhea and clinda use.  Drug fever would be dx of
   exclusion.
   - Cont vanc / aztreonam
   - Clinda d/c'ed and c. diff ordered.
   - Send urinalysis and culture, F/U sputum legionella culture
   - Appreciate ID input
   # L Leg Contracture: Consider central process, vs inflammatory or
   infectious arthropathy
   - Await MRI read, d/w neurosurgery
   - Monitor L knee, hip, if tappable effusion tap given history of
   hematogenous infection
   # Diffuse Body Pain: Still in marked discomfort despite fentanyl drip,
   neurontin.
   - Increase fentanyl patch, neurontin
   # Anemia: Hct stable s/p 1 unit PRBC yesterday.  No obvious source of
   bleeding.  Stool occult negative.
   - Hct goal >25.
   #Afib RVR: Initially on amio gtt, now transitioned to PO.
   - Amio 400mg PO tid x1 week, started Sunday [**10-23**], tapering.  Check EKG.
   - In sinus rhythm, so no anticoagulation at this time.  On aspirin.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and a recent complicated hospital course including an epidural abscess, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, atrial thrombus, and NSTEMI. He is currently in the ICU for aspiration pneumonia (PNA) with dense, large right-sided infiltrate, now improving. The patient is on mechanical ventilation due to hypoxemic respiratory failure likely caused by hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration PNA plus pulmonary edema. He is also being treated for enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis, which are stable. The patient has persistent fevers, and there is a possibility of Clostridium difficile infection given increased diarrhea and clindamycin use. He is on broad-spectrum antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure due to HAP/aspiration PNA + pulmonary edema.
2. Enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis.
3. Clostridium difficile infection.
4. Drug fever.
5. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
6. L leg contracture.
7. Diffuse body pain.
8. Anemia.
9. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib RVR).

Please note that this summary and potential medical complications are based on

- The patient has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics (vanc/aztreonam) for aspiration/HAP and has had cultures negative.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and atrial thrombus. The patient presented with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) and is currently improving. He is experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure on the ventilator, likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration PNA plus pulmonary edema. The patient's fever is persistent, but this is likely due to known PNA. Enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis are stable, with no new source identified. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is unlikely given recent anticoagulation and now subcutaneous heparin. Effusions on the CT do not appear to be empyemas. Clostridium difficile (C. diff) is a possibility due to increased diarrhea and clindamycin use. Drug fever would be diagnosed by exclusion. The patient's altered mental status is a concern, as he only responds to pain. A head CT has been ordered due to poor mental status. The patient also has a leg contracture, which may be due to a central process, inflammatory or infectious arthropathy. An MRI read is awaited, and neurosurgery input is appreciated. The patient is still in marked discomfort despite a fentanyl drip

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, chronic renal insufficiency, and recent hospitalization for an epidural abscess and bacteremia. He presented with fevers and lethargy and subsequently intubated for pneumonia of the entire right lung. The patient has been on vancomycin (day 10 of 14) and aztreonam (day 10 of 14) and clindamycin stopped on day 7 of 10. His respiratory failure is due to right aspiration pneumonia. He has also been experiencing leg contracture and pain. The patient's fever and rising leukocyte count indicate possible infection, with negative fungal markers and pending fungal cultures. Legionella sputum and urine tests were negative, and urinalysis done yesterday was negative as well. The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, troponin leak, altered mental status, and anemia. The assessment includes renal failure, fever, abdominal pain, chronic pain, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, respiratory failure (not ARDS), altered mental status, and history of sepsis without organ dysfunction.

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic renal insufficiency. He was recently hospitalized for an epidural abscess and bacteremia caused by pan-sensitive enterococcus. The patient presented to the hospital with fevers and lethargy and subsequently intubated for pneumonia of the entire right lung. 

The patient's current medical complications include respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia, renal failure, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, altered mental status, and troponin leak. 

The patient has been treated with vancomycin, aztreonam, and clindamycin for the pneumonia, but these antibiotics were stopped due to a rash. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%. 

The patient's left leg shows signs of contracture, which may be related to gout or muscle spasm. Pain control is a concern as the patient has chronic pain exacerbated by sedation weaning. 

The patient's fever and rising leukocyte count are not explained by the current infection or imaging studies. Blood cultures, urine cultures, and a CT scan of the abdomen/chest should be done to investigate further.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a chief complaint of fever. The patient has been admitted to the ICU with several medical conditions, including acute renal failure, fever, history of abdominal pain, chronic pain, alteration in nutrition, severe sepsis with organ dysfunction, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, respiratory failure (not ARDS), altered mental status, and history of sepsis without organ dysfunction.

The patient's vital signs include a maximum temperature of 102.5Â°F, current temperature of 98.4Â°F, heart rate between 66-97 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 109/40 mmHg to 158/54 mmHg, respiratory rate between 7-15 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 98%. The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a fluid balance with a total intake of 2,985 mL and total output of 1,895 mL. The patient is receiving various medications, including fentanyl, vancomycin, and aztreonam.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, elevated blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, potassium, and lactate levels. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range, with the exception of slightly low calcium levels. The patient's arterial blood gas analysis shows a respiratory acidosis with a pH of 7.28.

Physical examination reveals the patient's peripheral vascular pulses are not assessed

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complications including an epidural abscess, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. He presents with aspiration pneumonia with a dense, large right-sided infiltrate, which is now improving. The patient is experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure on ventilator support, likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration pneumonia, along with pulmonary edema. His chest X-ray shows improvement.

The patient has been on antibiotics (vancomycin and aztreonam) for aspiration/HAP but is still febrile. Enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis are stable with no new source identified. Deep vein thrombosis is unlikely due to recent anticoagulation and now subcutaneous heparin. Effusions on CT do not appear to be empyemas, and Galactomannan and glucan tests are negative. Rash and eosinophilia suggest a possible drug fever, so the antibiotics have been changed to daptomycin. ID input is appreciated, and meropenem is considered for any decompensation.

The patient's mental status is altered, likely from oversedation due to pain regimen. He responds only to pain, and his head CT is unremarkable. A pain consult has been ordered

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, atrial thrombus, and NSTEMI. The patient presented with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) with dense, large right-sided infiltrate, which is now improving. He is currently experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure on mechanical ventilation and is likely to have hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)/aspiration PNA plus pulmonary edema.

The patient has persistent fevers, known PNA, but would expect him to be afebrile at this time from PNA. Enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis are stable, with no new source identified. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is unlikely given recent anticoagulation and now subcutaneous heparin. Effusions on CT do not appear to be empyemas. Glucan/Galactomannan negative. Clostridium difficile (C. diff) is a possibility given increased diarrhea and clindamycin use. Drug fever would be diagnosed by exclusion.

The patient also has altered mental status, responding only to pain, with a head CT given poor mental status. There is a concern for central nervous system (CNS) infection or inflammatory process causing leg contracture. An MRI read

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic renal insufficiency. He was admitted to the ICU for fevers, lethargy, and subsequent intubation due to pneumonia of the entire right lung. The patient has been diagnosed with acute renal failure, fever, chronic pain, altered mental status, sepsis, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, and right leg contracture.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Renal Failure: The patient is experiencing acute renal failure, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances, fluid overload, and the accumulation of waste products in the body.
2. Infection: The patient has a history of fevers and is currently on antibiotics. Infections can worsen renal function, cause sepsis, and lead to further complications.
3. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which increases the risk of stroke, heart failure, and arrhythmias.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure may require prolonged mechanical ventilation, increasing the risk of ventilator-associated pneumonia and lung injury.
5. Right Leg Contracture: The patient has a right leg contracture, which may be due to immobility or joint issues. It can lead to pressure ulcers, deep vein thrombosis, and decreased mobility.
6. Chronic Pain: The patient's chronic pain needs

The patient is a well-nourished individual who is experiencing severe pain and has been admitted to the ICU. The patient has a history of chronic pain, renal failure, fever, altered mental status, sepsis, atrial fibrillation, hypotension, respiratory failure, and altered nutrition. The patient is currently on multiple medications including fentanyl, pantoprazole, heparin sodium, hydralazine, and others. The patient's vital signs show high blood pressure, normal heart rate, low respiratory rate, and normal oxygen saturation. The patient's lab results indicate elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin level, high potassium level, and normal liver function tests. The patient has undergone several procedures and interventions in the ICU.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Renal failure: The patient has a history of renal failure, which can be exacerbated by factors such as dehydration, medication side effects, or sepsis.
2. Infection/sepsis: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count suggest the possibility of an infection. Sepsis can lead to organ dysfunction and potentially worsen the patient's condition.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to their underlying medical condition or complications from mechanical ventilation. Weaning off the ventilator could be challenging due to the patient's pain and mental status changes.
4. Hypertension: The patient's high blood pressure needs to be carefully managed to prevent complications

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic renal insufficiency. He was admitted from rehabilitation for fevers and lethargy, intubated for pneumonia of the entire right lung, and diagnosed with acute respiratory failure. The patient has been receiving various antibiotics for suspected infections, including Vancomycin and Aztreonam, which were stopped on day 12, and Clindamycin, which was stopped on day 7.

The patient's current condition includes renal failure, fever, chronic pain, altered mental status, sepsis (previously without organ dysfunction), atrial fibrillation, and respiratory failure. He has also shown signs of leg contracture, pain that cannot be adequately controlled during sedation weaning, rising leukocytosis, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

Medical Complications:

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and NSTEMI. The patient presented with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) with dense, large right-sided infiltrate, which is now improving. He is currently experiencing hypoxemic respiratory failure on the ventilator and has been diagnosed with hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration PNA plus pulmonary edema. The patient's fever is persistent, likely due to known PNA, but other sources have been ruled out. Enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis are stable, and there is no evidence of empyemas in the effusions on CT. The patient's altered mental status is likely due to oversedation from the pain regimen, and a head CT was unremarkable. The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response has been managed with amiodarone, and long-term anticoagulation plans have been deferred until closer to discharge.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient is currently on the ventilator due to hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely caused by HAP/aspiration PNA plus pulmonary edema. Monitoring and supportive care are crucial to manage this condition.
2. Persistent fevers: The patient's

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, NSTEMI. He presented with aspiration pneumonia with dense, large right-sided infiltrate, now improving.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure on vent: Likely due to HAP/aspiration pneumonia + pulmonary edema. CXR improving.
- Finished 14 days of vanc/aztreonam for aspiration/HAP
- Bronchodilators
- Wean to PS; mental status currently main barrier to extubation given pain/sedation
- I/Os even
- Day 12 of ET tube
   if not extubated tomorrow, then will d/w family
   possible trach Thurs/Fri

2. Persistent fevers: Known PNA
- Change abx to daptomycin for enterococcus endocarditis
- Appreciate ID input
- Meropenem for any decompensation
- Consider fungal coverage if does not defervesce given yeast in sputum/urine.

3. Altered Mental Status: Likely from oversedation due to pain regimen.
- Wean sedation
- Pain consult to come by formally when patient extubated and interactive

4. L knee/great toe pain: Concerning for gout. Low suspicion for septic joints. No fluid on knee U/S.
- Discuss possible septic joint with ID, but will hold on MRI for now
- Start steroids
- Send uric acid level

5. Afib RVR: Initially on amio gtt, now transitioned to PO.
- Amio started Sunday [**10-23**], tapered to 200mg tid [**10-30**].
- In sinus rhythm, so no anticoagulation at this time. On aspirin.
- Long term anticoagulation plan deferred for closer to discharge.

6. HTN: Likely due to weaning sedation
- Continue to uptitrate hydralazine

7. Emesis: NPO with OG tube to suction to prevent further aspiration events.

   dense, large R-sided infiltrate, now improving.

   PNA + pulmonary edema.  CXR improving.

   - Wean to PS; mental status currently main barrier to extubation given
   pain/sedation
   - I/Os even
   - Day 12 of ET tube
 if not extubated tomorrow, then will d/w family
   possible trach Thurs/Fri
   # Persistent fevers: Known PNA
 but would expect him to be afebrile at
   this time from PNA.  Enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and
   discitis stable. No new source identified. No DVT.  Effusions on CT do
   not appear to be empyemas.  Glucan/Galactomannan negative.  C. diff
   negative.   Rash and eosinophilia points to possible drug fever
   - Change abx to daptomycin for enterococcus endocarditis
   - Appreciate ID input
 Meropenem for any decompensation
   - [**Month (only) 8**] consider fungal coverage if does not defervesce given yeast in
   sputum/urine.
   # Altered Mental Status: Likely from oversedation due to pain regimen.

   - Wean sedation

   # L knee/great toe pain: Concerning for gout.  Low suspicion for septic

He was recently hospitalized for an epidural abscess and bacteremia with pan-sensitive Enterococcus. He presented from a rehabilitation facility with fevers and lethargy, subsequently intubated for pneumonia of the entire right lung. The patient is currently in the ICU with multiple medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Renal Failure: The patient has a history of chronic renal insufficiency and acute renal failure.
2. Fever: The patient has been experiencing fevers, which could be due to an ongoing infection.
3. Abdominal Pain: The patient has a history of abdominal pain and tenderness, although imaging results are negative for any acute issues.
4. Chronic Pain: The patient has chronic pain, exacerbated by weaning sedation.
5. Sepsis: The patient has a history of severe sepsis with organ dysfunction.
6. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient had episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, requiring cardiovascular support.
7. Respiratory Failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia.
8. Altered Mental Status: The patient initially had altered mental status likely due to fevers and infection, but further evaluation is needed since the patient

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and chronic renal insufficiency. He was admitted to the ICU for respiratory distress and was found to have aspiration pneumonia in his right lung. He has been intubated and placed on pressure support ventilation (PSV). The patient has been weaned off sedation and is now on minimal sedation.

The patient has several medical complications, including acute renal failure, fever, altered mental status, chronic pain, sepsis (with organ dysfunction), atrial fibrillation, and respiratory failure. The cause of these complications is likely due to his recent hospitalization for an epidural abscess and bacteremia, as well as his current condition of right aspiration pneumonia.

The patient's current medications include gabapentin for pain control, fentanyl patch, and IV fentanyl for sedation weaning. He is also on amiodarone for atrial fibrillation and aspirin and statin for troponin leak. His blood cultures, urine cultures, and fungal markers are pending, and he is being evaluated for possible sources of infection.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient has acute respiratory failure due to right aspiration pneumonia. This requires ongoing monitoring and management, including continued use of PSV and weaning off sedation.

2. Sepsis with organ dysfunction: The patient has severe sepsis with organ

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and chronic renal insufficiency (CRI) presenting with respiratory distress. He has been admitted multiple times recently for an epidural abscess and bacteremia caused by Enterococcus species. The patient presented with fevers and lethargy, leading to intubation due to pneumonia affecting the entire right lung.

Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient initially had right aspiration pneumonia, but there has been improvement. He is currently off antibiotics and receiving treatment with daptomycin for Enterococcus infection. A spontaneous breathing trial (SBT) went well, but he is still not extubated.

2. Left Leg Contracture: The patient had a left leg contracture that improved after extubation and discontinuation of sedation. A lower extremity venous ultrasound (LENS) done yesterday was negative for deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The left knee is no longer tender, reducing concerns about gout.

3. Pain Control: The patient experiences chronic pain, which worsens during sedation weaning. He is being continued on gabapentin and fentanyl patch for pain management.

4. Fevers/Rising Leukocytosis: The patient's fevers and leukocytosis have improved, possibly due to drug fever/rash caused by vancomycin

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and NSTEMI. The patient presented with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) with dense, large right-sided infiltrate, now improving. The patient's current condition includes hypoxemic respiratory failure on ventilator, likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration PNA + pulmonary edema. The patient has been on 14 days of vancomycin and aztreonam for aspiration/HAP, and is currently improving.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure on vent: Likely HAP/aspiration PNA + pulmonary edema. CXR improving.
   - Finished 14 days of vanc/aztreonam for aspiration/HAP
   - Bronchodilators
   - Wean to PS; mental status currently main barrier to extubation given pain/sedation
   - I/Os even
   - Day 12 of ET tube
   if not extubated tomorrow, then will d/w family possible trach Thurs/Fri

2. Persistent fevers: Known PNA
   but would expect him to be afebrile at this time from PNA. Enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complications including an epidural abscess, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, and septic emboli to the brain. He is currently in the ICU for aspiration pneumonia with dense right-sided infiltrate, now improving. He has hypoxemic respiratory failure on vent likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or aspiration pneumonia (PNA) with pulmonary edema. He has completed 14 days of vancomycin and aztreonam for HAP. His persistent fevers are likely due to known PNA, and his enterococcus aortic valve endocarditis and discitis are stable with no new source identified. The patient's rash and eosinophilia suggest a possible drug fever, and he has been afebrile for 24 hours. He is currently on daptomycin for six weeks for enterococcus endocarditis. The patient's altered mental status is likely from oversedation due to pain regimen, and he has responded well today. His head CT is unremarkable. He will be taken off sedation and assessed for pain once extubated and may consider a pain consult. The patient's left knee and great toe pain are concerning for gout but have low suspicion for septic joints, and no fluid was found on knee ultrasound. Observation will be continued for now as he has improved. The patient

- The patient's left knee/great toe pain is concerning for gout, but there is low suspicion for septic joints. No fluid is present on knee ultrasound.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and chronic renal insufficiency (CRI). He presented from a rehabilitation facility with fevers and lethargy and was subsequently intubated for pneumonia of the entire right lung. The patient has been on invasive ventilation but was successfully extubated today. There have been no overnight events. The patient has allergies to ampicillin and ceftriaxone. He received a course of vancomycin and aztreonam, which was stopped, and is still on daptomycin for the treatment of enterococcus.

The patient has several medical complications including hypertension, acute renal failure, fever, chronic pain, altered mental status, sepsis, atrial fibrillation, respiratory failure, and altered nutrition. He also has a history of aspiration, leg contracture, gout, anemia, and a right atrial appendage thrombus.

Plan:
- Continue monitoring and treating the patient's multiple medical conditions.
- Wean off hydralazine and transition to home medications for hypertension.
- Start amlodipine 10 and metoprolol 25 tid (home dose is 100).
- Continue post-pyloric doffhoff for recurrent aspiration.
- Continue gabapentin and fentanyl patch for pain control.
- Follow up blood cultures and urine cultures.
- Follow up

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and chronic renal insufficiency (CRI) who was recently hospitalized for an epidural abscess and bacteremia caused by Pan-sensitive Enterococcus. The patient presented to the hospital with fevers and lethargy and subsequently required intubation due to pneumonia affecting the entire right lung.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient had right aspiration pneumonia, which has now improved. He is off antibiotics and receiving treatment with Daptomycin for Enterococcus. The patient successfully underwent extubation and is doing well on a face tent. Albuterol nebs are given as needed, and the patient's oxygen level is being weaned as tolerated.

2. Left leg contracture: The patient's left leg contracture has improved after extubation and without sedation. A LENIS (left extremity nerve injury survey) done yesterday was negative for clot. The left knee is less tender to palpation, reducing concerns about gout. The patient will continue to be monitored, and follow-up recommendations from rheumatology and nursing will be implemented.

3. Pain control: The patient experiences chronic pain that has been exacerbated by weaning sedation. However, since sedation has been completely weaned, pain management strategies such as continuing gabapentin and f

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complications including an epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and NSTEMI. He was admitted with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) and a dense, large right-sided infiltrate. He has now improved and was extubated on November 2nd.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient is at risk for hypoxemic respiratory failure due to HAP/aspiration PNA and pulmonary edema. The patient has been extubated and is on bronchodilators and diuretics for management.

2. Persistent fevers: The patient initially had persistent fevers, which are now resolved and presumed to be drug fever. The patient is on daptomycin for enterococcus endocarditis and will continue this treatment for six weeks. ID input is appreciated, and meropenem may be considered for any decompensation.

3. Pain: The patient has knee pain concerning for gout. There is low suspicion for septic joints, and no fluid was found on knee ultrasound. Observation is being continued as the patient has improved. A pain consult may be considered in a few days once the mental status is fully cleared.

4. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (Afib RVR): The patient initially

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and NSTEMI. The patient presented with aspiration pneumonia with dense, large right-sided infiltrate, now improving. The patient was extubated on 11/2. 

The patient's current conditions include hypoxemic respiratory failure, likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)/aspiration pneumonia (PNA) plus pulmonary edema. The patient finished 14 days of vancomycin/aztreonam for aspiration/HAP. The patient also has persistent fevers, now afebrile - presumed drug fever. The patient is on daptomycin for six weeks from 9/30 for enterococcus endocarditis. 

Other issues include pain in the knee, concerning for gout, with low suspicion for septic joints. No fluid on knee ultrasound. The patient is being observed for now as improved, with consideration for a pain consult in a few days when mental status is fully cleared. The patient has atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFRVR), initially on amiodarone (amio) gtt, now transitioned to PO. 

The patient also has hypertension, and the plan is to uptitrate hydralazine. The patient has aspiration

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), and chronic renal insufficiency (CRI). He was admitted to the ICU for fevers and lethargy, and subsequently intubated for pneumonia affecting the entire right lung. The patient also had a recent hospitalization for an epidural abscess and bacteremia caused by pan-sensitive enterococcus.

The patient's medical complications include:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient initially had right aspiration pneumonia but has now improved and is off antibiotics. He is still on daptomycin for treatment of enterococcus.
2. Left leg contracture: The patient had a left leg contracture but it has improved after extubation and no longer exhibits signs of gout. Further follow-up with rheumatology and nursing recommendations is needed.
3. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension that is being managed with oral hydralazine. It will be transitioned to home medications including amlodipine 10 mg and metoprolol 25 mg three times a day. The hydralazine will be weaned as these medications take effect.
4. Vancomycin-resistant enterococcal endocarditis (VRE endocarditis): The patient received a course of daptomycin, which will finish on November 14th.
5. Recurrent aspiration: The patient

Based on the provided information, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient has a history of asthma, gout, benign hypertension, chronic pain, alteration in nutrition, and severe sepsis with organ dysfunction.
- The patient was admitted with fevers, lethargy, and right lung pneumonia. They were intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation.
- The patient's respiratory failure improved, and they were taken off antibiotics after completing a course of vancomycin and aztreonam.
- The patient is currently on a two-week course of daptomycin for VRE endocarditis.
- There is no longer evidence of leg contracture or atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
- The patient experienced recurrent aspiration and has a post-pyloric Dobhoff tube placed.
- Pain control measures, including gabapentin and fentanyl patch, are being continued.
- The patient's fevers and leukocytosis have improved, likely due to stopping vancomycin and aztreonam.
- Follow-up blood cultures and urine cultures are recommended.
- The patient had an episode of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, which resolved with IV loading dose. They are now on oral amiodarone.
- Troponin leak was observed after an episode of atrial fibrillation earlier in the week. CK levels are slightly elevated, but MB is flat. This could be related to ischemia in the setting

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complications including an epidural abscess, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and NSTEMI.
- The patient was admitted with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) and dense, large right-sided infiltrate, now improving and extubated on 11/2.
- The patient has been treated for 14 days with vancomycin and aztreonam for aspiration/HAP.
- The patient has hypernatremia and is advised to follow fluid restrictions.
- The patient has enterococcus endocarditis and is on daptomycin for six weeks.
- The patient has experienced drug fever and rashes from other antibiotics.
- The patient is in sinus rhythm, so no anticoagulation is required at this time, but will be planned for closer to discharge.
- The patient has hypertension and is being uptitrated with hydralazine.
- The patient has an aspiration risk and failed swallow study with tachypnea, desaturation, and evidence of applesauce in the pharynx.
- A post-pyloric Dobhoff tube was placed, and total parenteral nutrition (TPN) may be considered depending on how the patient tolerates tube feeding.
- The patient's blood work shows elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, platelet count, and

Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and NSTEMI. He presented with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) and dense, large right-sided infiltrate. The patient has been treated with antibiotics for aspiration/HAP and extubated on 11/2. He is now showing signs of improvement.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is a concern, as indicated by the dense, large right-sided infiltrate and the initial need for mechanical ventilation. There is a likelihood of Hypoxemic Respiratory Failure due to HAP/aspiration PNA plus pulmonary edema. The patient has been extubated, but continuous monitoring is necessary.
2. Hypernatremia: The patient has an elevated sodium level, which needs to be corrected to prevent potential complications related to fluid imbalance.
3. Enterococcus endocarditis: The patient has been diagnosed with enterococcus endocarditis, for which he is on daptomycin therapy. This condition requires long-term treatment and close monitoring to prevent further complications.
4. Pain: The patient was experiencing pain initially but has shown improvement. Pain management should continue to be addressed to ensure patient comfort.
5. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response:

The patient presented with aspiration pneumonia with dense, large right-sided infiltrate, which is now improving and the patient has been extubated.

The assessment and plan include the following:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: Likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP)/aspiration pneumonia (PNA) plus pulmonary edema. The patient finished 14 days of vancomycin (Vanc)/aztreonam for aspiration/HAP and is currently on bronchodilators and autodiuresis.
2. Hypernatremia: Fluid restriction for weight-based fluid management.
3. Right upper extremity (RUE) swelling: Likely due to positioning and diuresis. An ultrasound (U/S) is recommended to rule out deep vein thrombosis (DVT).

5. Pain: Observation for now as improved.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including an epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction. He presented with aspiration pneumonia (PNA) with a dense, large right-sided infiltrate, which is now improving and he has been extubated.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxemic respiratory failure: The patient may be at risk for hypoxemic respiratory failure due to aspiration pneumonia and pulmonary edema.
2. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypernatremia, which may require further evaluation and management.
3. RUE swelling: The patient has right upper extremity swelling, which could be due to positioning and diuresis. Further investigation is needed to rule out deep vein thrombosis (DVT).
4. Enterococcus endocarditis: The patient is being treated with daptomycin for enterococcus endocarditis. Drug fever and rashes from other antibiotics have occurred.
5. Pain: The patient is being observed for pain management as he has improved.
6. Atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (afib RVR): The patient was initially on amiodarone but transitioned to oral medication. It is mentioned that amiodarone was started on Sunday, October 23rd

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, benign hypertension, and chronic renal insufficiency. He was admitted to the ICU from rehab for fevers and lethargy, subsequently intubated for pneumonia of the entire right lung. The patient had an episode of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response requiring CVL placement and Neo for blood pressure support. He also experienced sepsis, acute respiratory failure, altered mental status, and right leg contracture, which has resolved. The patient has a history of Enterococcus bacteremia and epidural abscess. He is currently on a two-week course of daptomycin for treatment of Enterococcus. The patient's current medications include albuterol nebs as needed, fact tent, weaning oxygen, amlodipine 10, metoprolol 37.5 tid, gabapentin, fentanyl patch, amiodarone, aspirin, statin, and restarting home beta-blocker. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent aspiration: The patient failed superficial cough and swallow evaluation, indicating a risk for recurrent aspiration.
2. Chronic pain: The patient has chronic pain exacerbated by weaning sedation.
3. VRE endocarditis: The patient is currently on a course of daptomycin, which will finish on [**11-14**].
4. Troponin leak: The

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 76-year-old male with a history of asthma, gout, and recent complicated hospital course including epidural abscess requiring surgery, enterococcus bacteremia, aortic endocarditis, septic emboli to the brain, and NSTEMI. The patient presented with aspiration pneumonia, which is now improving and the patient has been extubated. He also had HAP/aspiration pneumonia with pulmonary edema, which resolved after finishing 14 days of vancomycin and aztreonam. The patient is currently being treated for enterococcus endocarditis with daptomycin for 6 weeks. An MRI showed stable L5-S1 discitis/osteomyelitis since September 28th, but will be managed separately from endocarditis. The patient's hypernatremia has been stabilized but not improved with increased free H2O flushes. He will continue with enteric free H2O and receive 500cc D5W today. The patient's right lower extremity swelling is likely due to positioning and diuresis, so an ultrasound will be done to rule out deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (RVR) has resolved, and he is now in sinus rhythm. He will follow up with cardiology as an outpatient and will not be on anticoagulation at this time. The patient's hypertension will continue to
